awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Dual-Source Single-Crystal X-ray Diffractometer
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is supported by the Major Research Instrumentation and the Chemistry Research Instrumentation programs. Professor Mykhailo Shatruk from Florida State University and colleagues Igor Alabugin, Susan Latturner, Biwu Man and James Frederich have acquired a microfocus, dual source single crystal diffractometer. In general, an X-ray diffractometer allows accurate and precise measurements of the full three-dimensional structure of a molecule, including bond distances and angles, and provides accurate information about the spatial arrangement of a molecule relative to neighboring molecules. The studies described here impact many areas, including organic and inorganic chemistry, materials chemistry and biochemistry. This instrument is an integral part of teaching as well as research and research training of graduate and undergraduate students in chemistry and biochemistry at this institution. Students are involved in chemical and protein research. The resource is also utilized by neighboring primarily undergraduate institutions. 

The proposal is aimed at enhancing research and education at all levels. It is especially useful for studying temperature-, and light-induced spin-state switching in molecule-based materials, for the identification of compounds prepared using molten metal fluxes. The diffractometer is also being used in investigations of phosphorescent molecules from halide perovskites for energy applications, and for structurally characterizing supramolecular species made from contorted carbon-rich molecules and nanomaterials. It is also employed for the characterization of synthesized natural products used to evaluate protein-protein interaction modulators.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This grant has funded the purchase and installation of a new state-of-the-art single-crystal X-ray diffraction (SCXRD) system at the FSU Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. The instrument was installed in March of 2019 and opened to general usage a month later.

The new SCXRD system has dramatically increased the rate and quality of crystallographic work, allowing researchers to carry out more than 2500 experiments over the span of slightly more than 2.5 years. The results of these research activities already have been disseminated in several high-impact publications, and more research articles are on the way.

The SCXRD instrument has facilitated research projects carried out by 22 research groups within FSU and by 5 groups outside of FSU, including researchers at HBCU and PUIs. More than 70 graduate students and postdocs have received training in the usage of the SCXRD system and in the fundamentals of X-ray diffraction and crystallography. Currently, the SCXRD is used on the 24/7 basis, with minimal interruptions due to scheduled maintenance periods.

As part of training efforts associated with the new SCXRD operations, in January of 2020 we held a joint FSU-Rigaku X-ray Diffraction and Crystallography Workshop in Tallahassee, FL. The workshop was attended by 75 participants, about half of whom were non-FSU participants. The workshop featured lectures on X-ray diffraction and crystallography and hands-on training with X-ray instrumentation.

In addition to training graduate students and postdocs, an experiment that involves SCXRD has been implemented in the new Chemistry of Materials lab curriculum that will be offered to undergraduate students in spring of 2022, for the first time. This experiment aims to complement the lectures on X-ray diffraction and crystallography offered during the regular Chemistry of Materials course for undergraduate students.


Last Modified: 11/29/2021
Modified by: Mykhailo Shatruk

Images (1 of )
  • The new single-crystal X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku Synergy-S) was installed in the X-ray Crystallography Center of the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry, at Florida State University, in spring of 2019.
    Dr. Xinsong Lin

    The SCXRD system at FSU Chemistry and Biochemistry
  • The FSU-Rigaku X-ray Diffraction Workshop was held in January of 2020 at the Department of Chemistry and Biochemistry. The workshop attracted 75 participants from FSU and nearby institutions.
    Dr. Michael Shatruk
    Public Domain
    Mykhailo Shatruk
    FSU-Rigaku X-ray Diffraction Workshop
